key_points: Colin Powell, the first Black U.S. Secretary of State, died on Oct. 18 at the age of 84 from COVID-19 complications.
Powell had an estimated net worth of $60 million at the time of his death.
He is survived by his wife, Alma Johnson, their daughters Linda and Annemarie, and son Michael.
His career included roles as National Security Advisor, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and a military retirement in 1993.
Powell earned income from his autobiography and speaking engagements, including $7 million from 109 speaking engagements in 2000.
His military career spanned several presidencies, from Nixon to George W. Bush, and began with a White House Fellowship in 1972.
Former President George W. Bush praised Powell's service, noting his receipt of the Presidential Medal of Freedom twice.
Post-military, Powell engaged in entrepreneurial ventures and served on various boards and campaigns.
He founded Americaâ€™s Promise Alliance in 1997, focusing on improving young people's lives.
Rep. Jamaal Bowman reflected on Powell's inspirational legacy as a figure of high accomplishment from NYC and City College.
spokespersons: Jamaal Bowman (U.S. Representative, New York's 16th Congressional District)
